text: Melina's release from the spool like a
huge jellyfish rising in the sky a nasa
balloon takes off from a launch pad in
Hawaii underneath what appears to be a
flying saucer called the low-density
supersonic decelerator or ldsd up it
drifted serenely sedately climbing up to
a height of around 37 kilometres then
inbuilt rockets propelled it even
further lifting it to the edge of space
the hope is the ldsd will be used as a
landing vehicle the thing they want to
land it on is this Mars this test was
supposed to simulate the high speeds
expected during a descent on the Red
Planet well that was the plan but
unfortunately there was a hitch the huge
30 meter parachute the largest ever made
designed to bring the source of safely
down to the surface failed to open
properly you can hear the disappointment
the ldsd then plummeted into the Pacific
Ocean Engineers say more work will be
needed to strengthen the parachute
before another try next year as one
official said this is exactly why we do
tests like this Tim almond BBC news
